channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Peacekeepers in Darfur Killed in Attack by Gunmen
item.description: The attack was the deadliest single attack on the international force in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cafes Are Shut Down in Iraqi City Where Bomb Killed 39
item.description: The late-night blast in Kirkuk ripped through the Classico Cafe as patrons were enjoying tea and water pipes hours after the sunset meal that breaks the daylong Ramadan fast.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Battery Is Not Suspected in New Fire on Boeing 787
item.description: While investigators in London said they had not found the cause of the incident, the damage was not near either of the plane’s lithium-ion batteries.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW
item.media:description: The Queen of Sheba, a Boeing 787 Dreamliner that caught fire at Heathrow Airport on Friday.

item.title: Wheels: Mercedes Grand Prix Car Smashes Auction Records
item.description: With two of the car’s former drivers in attendance at the auction, the 1954 Mercedes-Benz W196 racer sold for nearly $30 million.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The Swiss Grand Prix on Aug. 22, 1954, won by Juan Manuel Fangio.

item.title: The Lede: Malala Yousafzai, Girl Shot by Taliban, Makes Appeal at U.N.
item.description: On her 16th birthday, Malala Yousafzai spoke at the United Nations and called on world leaders to make education available and compulsory for every child.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: The Lede: Parents Mourn Photographer Killed in Cairo
item.description: As the parents of Ahmed Assem, a 26-year-old photographer for a Muslim Brotherhood newspaper who was killed on Monday, mourned his death, Egyptian bloggers discovered disparaging remarks about Christians on the dead man’s Facebook page.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: An image of a graffiti tribute to Ahmed Assem, a photographer for a Muslim Brotherhood newspaper who was killed on Monday in Cairo, posted on Facebook by his brother.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Snowden
item.description: The Lede is following updates on Edward J. Snowden in Moscow, where the first image of him emerged from a meeting with rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:credit: Tanya Lokshina/Human Rights Watch, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo Airport on Friday, with Sarah Harrison of WikiLeaks at left.

item.title: City in Russia Unable to Kick Asbestos Habit
item.description: To residents of Asbest in Russia’s Ural Mountains, living with a pervasive carcinogen is the alternative to having no livelihood at all.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Olga Kravets for The New York Times
item.media:description: Every weekday afternoon in Asbest, Russia, miners set explosions in an asbestos strip mine, sending out clouds of carcinogenic dust.

item.title: Syria Weighs Its Tactics As Pillars of Its Economy Continue to Crumble
item.description: Syria is increasingly isolated in the face of a growing economic crisis, more reliant than ever on credit from its main remaining allies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The Grand Bazaar in Damascus. The value of Syria’s currency has plunged, so goods are costlier.

item.title: Dozens Injured in Northern Ireland as Protestants Riot Over Blocked Parade Route
item.description: Northern Ireland’s police commander blamed leaders of the Orange Order brotherhood for inciting running street battles in two parts of Belfast that lasted six hours and subsided early Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Police officers, with reinforcements from across Britain, were deployed in north Belfast as Orange Order members rioted.

item.title: Iraq Says It Can’t Halt Arms to Syria
item.description: Iraq’s foreign minister said his nation condemned the transfer of weapons from Iran to Syria through its airspace, but could not stop it from happening.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Loose Equipment Cited In Train Crash in France
item.description: The train accident outside Paris on Friday that killed at least six people and injured dozens of others was linked to a loose rail joint.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: French officials said the death toll at Brétigny-sur-Orge station might increase when the train wreckage was removed.

item.title: Russian Officials Say They Didn’t Receive an Asylum Request From Snowden
item.description: Senior Kremlin officials said Russia’s Federal Migration Service had not yet received a formal appeal for asylum from Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: An image of the former C.I.A. employee Edward J. Snowden after he met with some Russian public figures at a Moscow airport.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Infighting Undermines Anti-Assad Effort
item.description: Rebel factions in Syria are attacking each other in a series of kidnappings, killings and beheadings, as competition for recruits, weapons and the right to define the character of the future state boils over.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: After Protest, China Cancels Plans for Uranium Plant
item.description: The decision not to proceed with a uranium processing plant could complicate China’s plans to rely more on nuclear energy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: The police stood across from demonstrators on Friday during a protest against plans for a uranium processing plant in Jiangmen, China.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Coffee Shop Bomb Kills 19 in Iraq
item.description: A bomb went off in a crowded coffee shop late Friday in the ethnically disputed northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk, killing at least 19 and wounding more than two dozen.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Hun Sen Rival Is Pardoned
item.description: Prime Minister Hun Sen engineered a pardon for his most prominent rival on Friday, clearing the way for the self-exiled politician to return home and campaign in the general election.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: No New Inquiry Into Russian Spy’s Death
item.description: British officials have refused to hold a public inquiry into the death of the former Russian intelligence officer Alexander V. Litvinenko, a coroner said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Parades Stir Old Feuds
item.description: Protestant marchers in Belfast threw bricks and bottles at the police, who responded by spraying water at them as Northern Ireland’s annual parade season turned violent on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Retribution, Corruption or Both in Russia Mayor’s Bribery Case
item.description: Mayor Yevgeny R. Urlashov’s supporters say his prosecution is political, but government evidence that includes tapped phone calls and videos suggests otherwise.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Anna Solovyova/Rossyiskaya Gazeta, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor Yevgeny Urlashov, an opposition leader, was arrested last week.

item.title: Rights Groups Accuse Turkish Police of Excessive Force Against Protesters
item.description: A report released by an international medical rights group indicates that Turkish police displayed “excessive and unnecessary use of force” to stop antigovernment protests.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Before Blast, Hauling Oil Revived a Tiny Railroad
item.description: The Montreal, Maine and Atlantic Railway, part of Rail World Inc., was benefiting from a contract to move oil from North Dakota to New Brunswick, Canada, before last week’s train disaster in Quebec.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Edward Burkhardt, the president of Rail World, said the train’s engineer was at fault.

item.title: In Some Parts of Egypt, Bad Times Remained Bad
item.description: In the impoverished Egyptian town of Fayoum, conditions never improved during Mohamed Morsi’s presidency and the future now seems unsettled and unpromising.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Yusuf Sayman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Fayoum, Egypt, on Thursday.

item.title: Snowden Renews Plea for Moscow to Grant Asylum
item.description: After weeks of silence, the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden appealed for help in gaining asylum in Russia as he continued to seek passage to Latin America.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: An image of the former C.I.A. employee Edward J. Snowden after he met with some Russian public figures at a Moscow airport.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Kosovo’s Thaci Aspires to Statesmanship, but Guerrilla Past Haunts Him
item.description: Prime Minister Hashim Thaci, who led Kosovo’s bloody guerrilla war in the 1990s, is being hailed for a power-sharing deal with Serbia, but his history evokes the region’s ethnic enmities.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Thomasz Lazar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I was fighting on the right side of history, liberating my people from tyranny against a ruthless enemy engaged in a massive attempt at genocide.”
